creator: SunFounder Maker
title: How to DIY a Playable Keytar With Cardboard
description: This project is a DIY guide to building an ultralight, playable Keytar using cardboard, a multi-control board, switches, and some basic electronics. The Keytar combines the features of a keyboard and a guitar.
steps: Draw out a Keytar shape on cardboard.
Cut out two identical Keytar boards from cardboard.
Split the keys on one of the boards with a knife and mark the gaps with a marker pen.

Cut out the keyboard area on the second board and create gaps for the switches, ensuring the gaps match the switch width. Fix the switches under each key using a glue gun. Paste the two boards together using glue or double-sided tape.

Fix the pin header on the back of the Keytar board. Define the keys (C, D, E, F, G, A, B, C+) and control keys (Ctrl 1, Ctrl 2). Solder the normally-open pins of each switch to the pin header using cables.
Connect the COM pins of the switches to the GND pin of the Multi-Control board.
Insert the Multi-Control board to the pin header.
Download the required code library from the Multi-Control wiki page and the code from the Github Page.
Modify the code to match the Multi-Control pin definitions to the corresponding switches on the Keytar. Upload the modified code to the Multi-Control board.
Connect the Multi-Control to a computer via USB and use a MIDI software to play the Keytar.
